Award.AwardTitle: Optimal and Equilibrium Transport: Theory and Applications to Economics and Data Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is about developing some of the novel mathematical tools that are required for the new peer-to-peer economy. Recent years have witnessed the astonishing emergence of online matching platforms (such as Uber, Odesk, Airbnb, OkCupid), where agents seek to team up with each other to exchange various goods and services or form various partnerships. These platforms are provided with massive data on the populations of users, and need to take real-time decisions regarding market clearing, such as imposing surge prices, or suggesting assignments. The goal of this project is to expand the boundaries of a central tool: optimal transport theory, which was initiated in the 18th century but experienced a surge of research activity over the last decade, and which is very relevant for problems in matching, pricing, and data analysis.

The project is divided into three separate projects; the first two are related, and the third one is further apart. The first project will define the framework of equilibrium transportation, which extends optimal transport to equilibrium situations. It will focus on the semi-discrete case, where one of the distributions is continuous and the other one is discrete. In this setting, it will derive analytical properties of the solution such as existence, uniqueness, monotonicity, and lattice structure. This framework is applied to the solution of a problem on the labor market. In another application, it is extended to the case of equilibrium flows on networks. The second project will demonstrate the usefulness of the equilibrium transportation framework for computing equilibrium in markets such as the taxi market, which cannot be modeled as an optimal transport problem since prices are fixed; in this type of markets, demand and supply are balanced by a congestion cost induced by limited availability. The project will derive the properties of the equilibrium, and use the framework to study the surge pricing problem: when demand and supply are uncertain, which price should be set to minimize the expected market inefficiency? The third project will focus on computational challenges brought by the introduction (due to the PI and collaborators) of the notion of vector quantile regression in the statistical literature. The project will focus on iterated projection methods (which have been very successfully applied to classical optimal transport problems) for this new class of problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project consisted of extending the theory of optimal transport in directions that were meaningful to some applications, in particular in the domains of economics and data science.

The project was divided into three main stated goals:

1. Develop the theory of 'equilibrium transport' extending optimal transport in situations that are economically relevant.

2. Understand market clearing mechanism in the presence of price rigidities, and work out applications to assignment and surge pricing mechanisms.

3. Work out numerical methods for 'vector quantiles' based on optimal transport.

On the first goal, the PI and his collaborators have developed a systematic approach to the equilibrium problem by its entropic regularization in the paper [A2]. Existence results, uniqueness, computational algorithms and some applications to marital sorting and matching on the labor market are given in that paper. Applications are further developed in lecture series [B2] and in the TraME library [B1], The question of one-sided matching is shown to reformulate as a two-sided matching in [A3], and thus the tools developed for inference can be applied to one-sided matching markets. Paper [A5] has an application to the estimation of preferences in the same-sex marriage market. Tools from convex analysis are applied to the principal-agent problem with multiple agents problem in [A9].

The second goal investigated the link between price and nonprice market clearing, which is at the core of the second axis. This link is investigated in two working papers that are at submission stage, and in a paper on taxation in matching markets [A7]. The theory and computations are detailed in the ‘math+econ+code’ lecture series [B2]. A key tool for surge pricing is the estimation of matching affinities, which is done in paper [A4]. Paper [A10] provides a novel representation result for the nested logit model.

The third goal of the project was to further deepen the understanding of ‘vector quantile regression,’ which had recently been proposed by Carlier, Chernozhukov and Galichon as a tool to generate parametric representations of multivariate conditional quantiles, based on optimal transport methods. The case where the model is misspeficied is investigated in [A1], which provides a duality result extending the Monge-Kantorovich duality theorem, and shows existence of a dual solution under general conditions. The paper [A6] investigates the one-dimensional case, and shows that in this case, vector quantile regression is equivalent to running a series of classical quantile regressions with a monotonicity constraint. That paper also investigates the entropic regularization of the problem, and provides computational methods for to address that problem. Finally, the paper [A8] shows the use of multivariate quantiles in the identification of hedonic models, opening up the way of important applications of these techniques.

Over the lifespan of the project (2017-2020), ten published or forthcoming papers have appeared on these broad questions. In addition, several papers are at various making stage. An open-source software library, TraME, has been prototyped. The PI has also developed two lecture series with large dissemination goals.

 Project output

[A1] Guillaume Carlier, Victor Chernozhukov and Alfred Galichon (2017). “Vector quantile regression beyond the specified case”. Journal of Multivariate Analysis 161, pp. 96-102.

[A2] Alfred Galichon (2019), Scott Kominers and Simon Weber (2019). “Costly Concessions: An Empirical Framework for Matching with Imperfectly Transferable Utility”. Journal of Political Economy. 127, no. 6: pp. 2875-2925.

[A3] Pierre-André Chiappori, Alfred Galichon and Bernard Salanié (2019). “On Human Capital and Team Stability” (2019). Journal of Human Capital 13(2), pp.  236-259.

[A4] Arnaud Dupuy, Alfred Galichon and Yifei Sun (2019). “Estimating matching affinity matrix under low-rank constraints”. Information and Inference. 8 (4), pp. 677–689.

[A5] Edoardo Ciscato, Alfred Galichon, and Marion Goussé (2020). “Like Attract Like: A Structural Comparison of Homogamy Across Same-Sex and Different-Sex Households”. Journal of Political Economy 128, no. 2, pp. 740-781.

[A6] Guillaume Carlier, Victor Chernozhukov, Gwendoline De Bie and Alfred Galichon (2020+). “Vector quantile regression and optimal transport, from theory to numerics”. Accepted for publication, Empirical Economics.

[A7] Arnaud Dupuy, Alfred Galichon, Sonia Jaffe, and Scott Kominers (2020+) “Taxation in matching markets”. Accepted for publication, International Economic Review.

[A8] Victor Chernozhukov, Alfred Galichon, Marc Henry, and Brendan Pass (2020+) “Single market nonparametric identification of multi-attribute hedonic equilibrium models”. Accepted for publication, Journal of Political Economy.

[A9] Alfred Galichon (2020+) “Fritz John’s equation in mechanism design”. Accepted for publication, Economic Theory Bulletin.

[A10] Alfred Galichon (2020+) “On the representation of the nested logit model.” Accepted for publication, Econometric Theory.
